item.title: Dealing with Test Anxiety
item.description:
If you're experiencing test anxiety, you're far from alone. I had horrible test anxiety – it was to the point that my hands would be shaking uncontrollably halfway through a test and I'd have to stop writing entirely to just breathe. I've compiled some of the best tips I've come across, and I hope you find them helpful:

Learn your theory well enough to speed build with it
Be honest with yourself and identify gaps in your theory early on
Practice at speeds higher than you're testing at to build confidence
Maintain good posture with your elbows tucked into your waist and your steno machine low enough so that your wrists are stabilized on your thighs
Listen to audio that's faster than the speed you'll be testing at right before the exam
Just listen and imagine how you would write the faster audio, don't actually write anything
The test will seem manageable in comparison
Have a consistent pre-test routine that includes some exercise to burn off adrenaline
Find your inner zen during the test
Remember to breathe - deep breathing/box breathing will slow down your heartrate and ground you
Breathe in on "ready," and out on "begin"
Don't look at your writer - your focus will be pulled away from what you need to write now to what you've already written/failed to write (and any errors you've made)
Distract yourself just enough during the test so that the words flow through your fingers effortlessly
Suck on a hard candy or chew gum
Close your eyes and think of something that brings you peace and joy (a colour; a place; a friend, family member, or pet; or a memory)
Accept and embrace the nerves
There will probably be some nervousness (and its unfortunate symptoms) no matter what you do, so embrace it
Some of the best public speakers and musicians deal with performance/test anxiety; there's no need to feel embarrassed or ashamed
Write something for every word, even if it's gibberish
You can't edit or guess at what you meant to write if there's nothing written
Always transcribe!
More often than not, we think we did worse than we actually did
Tell yourself you got this
It's nothing you haven't done in practice
Remember that you're a steno star ⭐

item.title: Fundamentals
item.description:
A group of words that identify persons, places, things, qualities, concepts, or activities
Persons: Jane, teacher
Places: library, Edmonton
Things: book, computer
Qualities: honesty, bravery
Concepts: love, justice
Activities: swimming, writing
The object of a verb
Comes after an action verb to answer what? or whom?
He played the what? He played the guitar.
4 types of nouns:
Concrete nouns: tangible objects you can sense
Abstract nouns: feelings & qualities
Common nouns: general names
Proper nouns: specific names
Examples of each type of noun Concrete: apple, car Abstract: wisdom, love Common: city, dog Proper: London, Sarah
Don't capitalize common nouns after proper nouns unless they're part of an official name Sony products vs Grey Nuns Community Hospital


Singular nouns: name one person, place, or thing
Plural nouns: name two/more person, places, or things
Add s for most nouns
Add es for nouns ending in s, x, z, ch, or sh (including proper nouns)
Basic plurals Book → Books Box → Boxes
Barnes → Barneses (proper noun)


Irregular noun: a noun that forms the plural by changing its spelling
Compound noun: a noun that is made up of two/more words
Make the last element plural
If hyphenated, make the principal noun plural
If no principal noun, make the last element plural
Irregular/compound plurals Child → Children Toothbrush → Toothbrushes
Mother-in-law → Mothers-in-law No-show → No-shows

Weird plurals Party → Parties
Day → Days
Beatty → Beattys (proper noun) Knife → Knives Potato → Potatoes
Radio → Radios
Piano → Pianos (musical term)

Foreign noun








F for
A and
N nor
B but
O or
Y yet
S so

They connect:
Words
Phrases: a group of words without a subject and a verb
Clauses: a group of words with a subject and a verb
Conjunction joining words The dog is playful, friendly, and energetic.
Conjunction joining phrases I will practice steno in the morning, afternoon, and evening.
Conjunction joining clauses She enjoys writing, and he loves reading.

item.title: Body Organization
item.description:
Confined spaces within the body that contain internal organs
2 major cavities which are further subdivided:
Dorsal cavity: posterior (back) surface of the body
Cranial cavity: contains the brain
Spinal cavity: contains the spinal cord (spinal canal)
Ventral cavity: anterior (front) surface of the body
Thoracic cavity: contains the heart & lungs
Abdominal cavity: contains the stomach, liver, kidneys, small intestines, & large intestine
Pelvic cavity: contains the urinary bladder, parts of the intestine, & some reproductive organs
Abdominopelvic cavity: refers to both the abdominal and pelvic cavities
Diaphragm: major respiratory muscle used for breathing that separates the thoracic and abdominopelvic cavities







Helps to identify accurate directional medical terms
Standing straight
Arms at side
Head forward
Palms forward
Feet forward

The midline An imaginary line drawn down the center of the body from the top of the head to the feet
superior | cranial above; toward the head Example: head is superior to the neck
inferior | caudal below; toward the lower end of the body or tail Example: neck is inferior to the head
anterior | ventral front surface of the body Example: thoracic cavity is anterior to the spinal cavity
posterior | dorsal back surface of the body Example: spinal cavity is posterior to the thoracic cavity
medial toward the midline Example: big toe is medial to the small toe
lateral away from the midline Example: small toe is lateral to the big toe
proximal nearest from the point of attachment to the trunk/point of origin Example: stomach is proximal to the intestines
distal farthest from the point of attachment to the trunk/point of origin Example: intestines are distal to the stomach; stomach is distal to the throat
superficial near the surface of the body
deep away from the surface of the body
supine lying on the back, face up (palms facing up)
prone lying on the abdomen, face down (palms facing down)
plantar sole of the foot
dorsum upper portion of the foot


Plane: an exposed flat surface of the body

item.title: Skeletal System
item.description:
Protection and support of internal organs
Movement (act as rigid levers for muscles to pull on)
Storage area for calcium and phosphorus
Blood cell production in the bone marrow


3 types of bone cells:
Osteoblasts: create new bone cells
Osteocytes: have limited life span; form bone tissue
Osteoclasts: break down bone tissue to release minerals for reabsorption
Ossification: process of bone formation
Remodelling: breakdown and renewal of bone


Axial skeleton
Skull
Vertebral column (spine)
Protects the spinal cord
Each bone = vertebra
Vertebrae named by location and numbered:
7 cervical vertebrae (C1-C7)
12 thoracic vertebrae (T1-T12)
5 lumbar vertebrae (L-1-L5)
sacrum (5 fused bones)
coccyx (4 fused bones; tailbone)
Separated by intervertebral discs (pads of cartilage that act as shock absorbers)
Thoracic cage (chest)
12 ribs total (1-7 true, 8- 10 false, 11-12 floating)
Costal cartilage connects ribs together and to sternum (excluding for floating ribs)
Sternum (breast bone)
Hyoid bone (in the throat)
Appendicular skeleton
Pectoral girdle
Connects arms to the thoracic cage
Protects the heart and lungs
Pelvic girdle
Connects legs to the axial skeleton
Protects the pelvic organs
Sacroiliac joint: the circle formed by the right & left hip bones (ilia) joining with the sacrum
Limbs (arms & legs)
How to remember the number of vertebrae in each segment Breakfast at 7 (cervical)
Lunch at 12 (thoracic)
Supper at 5 (lumbar)











A place where two bones come together
Named after bones that form a union
Naming a joint The joint between the radius and the carpal (wrist) bones is the radiocarpal joint

Suture: immovable joint in skull
Synovial fluid is produced by the synovial membrane
Synovial membrane + articular cartilage = movement



Wear & tear
Osteoarthritis: degeneration of the articular cartilage
Rheumatoid arthritis: autoimmune disease which first attacks the joints
Osteoporosis: decreased bone density
Temporomandibular joint (TMJ) dysfunction
TMJ is the hinge that connects the jawbone to the temporal bone
Symptoms: pain/tenderness in/around the ear; problems opening/closing the mouth; and a clicking, popping sound when chewing
Cancers
Chondrosarcoma: cancer originating in the cartilage
Osteosarcoma: cancer originating in the bone
Fractures
A break or crack in a bone
Caused by injury or disease
Types of fractures:
Pathological fractures: bone breaks because it's weak from disease
Closed fracture (simple fracture): bone breaks but doesn't pierce the skin
Open fracture (compound fracture): bone breaks and pierces the skin
Comminuted fracture: bone breaks and splinters into fragments
Colles' fracture: fracture of the distal radius near the wrist
Greenstick fracture: bone partially breaks on one side but only bends on the other
Treatment types for fractures:
Reduction: place the bones back together
Open reduction: cut the skin to place the bones back together
Closed reduction: manually realign bones without cutting skin (x-ray after to check for proper alignment)
Immobilization: place a cast/splint over the broken bone to prevent movement

item.title: Muscular System
item.description:
Voluntary muscle: under conscious control
Involuntary muscle: not under conscious control
3 types of muscle tissue:
Visceral
Located in walls of internal organs
Under involuntary control
Cardiac
Located in heart
Under involuntary control
Skeletal
Located on top of bone
Under voluntary control
Ligaments attach bone to bone
Tendons attach muscle to bone
All skeletal muscles are connected to 2 bones
Muscles can only contract & relax; they work in pairs to accomplish a dual action
Flexion: bending a limb
Extension: straightening a limb
Hyperextension: overextending joint beyond anatomical position
Adduction: move toward midline
Abduction: move away from midline
Supination: turn palm forward
Pronation: turn palm backward
Eversion: move sole of foot outward away from midline
Inversion: move sole of foot inward toward midline
Dorsiflexion: bend foot upward
Plantar flexion: bend foot downward


Carpal tunnel syndrome
Tendons and ligaments in the small passageway in the wrist become inflamed when overused, which puts pressure on the median nerve
Symptoms: numbness, pain, tingling, and weakness
Muscular dystrophy (MD)
Degeneration of muscle tissue
Duchenne's muscular dystrophy is most common
Symptoms: muscular weakness; and loss of mobility, speech, and breathing
Strain (pulled muscle)
The tearing, twisting, overstretching, or overextension of muscles and tendons
Treatment: RICE (rest, ice, compression, elevation)
Sprain
Stretching of tearing of ligaments
Symptoms: swelling, inflammation, and bruising
Rotator cuff tendinitis
Inflammation of the rotator cuff (group of tendons that hold the shoulder joint in place)
Major cause: injury and degeneration
Fibromyalgia syndrome
Pain in fibrous tissues (muscles, tendons, and ligaments)
Associated with chronic fatigue syndrome
Symptoms: deep muscular aching; throbbing, burning, stabbing pain; and fatigue
Treatment: muscle relaxants, trigger point injections, physiotherapy, and acupuncture

item.title: Cardiovascular System
item.description:
Delivers oxygen and nutrients to the body's cells
Carries away carbon dioxide and waste products


Blood vessels: fuel line and transportation system
Veins: carry blood toward the heart (deoxygenated)
Arteries: carry blood away from the hear (oxygenated)
Capillaries: transfer oxygen to cells & carbon dioxide from cells
Heart: the most powerful muscle in the body
4 chambers of the heart:
Right atrium
Right ventricle
Left atrium
Left ventricle
Septum: wall dividing the right and left sections of the heart
Heart valves:
Atrioventricular valves: separate the atria from the ventricles; allow blood to flow only one way (atrium to ventricle)
Tricuspid valve (right side)
Mitral valve (bicuspid valve; left side)
Semilunar valves: allow blood to flow only from the ventricle to the arteries
Pulmonary valve (right side)
Aortic valve (left side)
How to remember the chambers and valves of the heart "TRy PULling My Aorta"
tricuspid, pulmonary, mitral, aortic "TRy doing the right thing"
tricuspid valve on the right side


The heart's electrical system
Sinoatrial node (SA node): the heart's natural pacemaker
Causes walls of the atria to contract and force blood into the ventricles
Electrocardiogram (ECG): a record of the electrical activity of the heart


Systolic pressure when the ventricles contract to pump blood out the the heart
Diastolic pressure: when the ventricles relax
Sphygmomanometer: a device used to measure blood pressure
Hypertension: high blood pressure
Hypotension: low blood pressure
Pulse: movement of the arteries relaxing and contracting in unison with the heartbeat
High vs. low blood pressure 130/80 = high blood pressure
130 = systolic pressure; 80 = diastolic pressure 90/60 = low blood pressure
90 = systolic pressure; 60 = diastolic pressure


Beginning of systole
Tricuspid and mitral valves close



End of systole/beginning of diastole
Aortic and pulmonary valves close



Cerebrovascular accident (CVA; stroke)
Blood stops flowing to the brain
Brain cells are damaged due to deprivation of oxygen and nutrients
Aneurysm
Abnormal swelling in the wall of the artery
A ruptured aneurysm is when the wall of the artery bursts and causes hemorrhage
Results in stroke, brain damage, coma, and death
Arrythmia
An irregular or abnormal heart rhythm
Coronary artery disease
Caused by plaques in the coronary arteries (build-up of fat and cholesterol deposits)
Treatment: coronary artery bypass surgery (surgical repair of a narrowed blood vessel)
Balloon angioplasty pushes plaque against the wall
A stent (wire-mesh tube) is inserted to keep the artery open
Cardiac arrest
The heart stops pumping blood
Congestive heart failure
The heart fails to pump blood effectively through the heart
Murmur
Whooshing extra heart sound
Myocardial infarction (heart attack)
Death of the heart muscle
Primary symptom: chest pain in males, shoulder/back pain in females
Treatment: coronary artery bypass surgery
A section of blood vessel from the leg/chest is implanted into the heart to reroute the blood around an obstruction

item.title: Obstetrics
item.description:
Gynecology: medical-surgical specialty dealing with female reproductive system in non-pregnant state
Obstetrics: medical-surgical specialty dealing with female reproductive system in pregnant state
OB/GYN: combination of gynecology & obstetrics
Gravida: pregnant
Primigravida: woman who has been pregnant once
Multigravida: woman who has been pregnant more than once
Para: having given birth (regardless of whether stillbirth)
Gravidity and parity Gravida 1, para 1 = woman who has been pregnant once & has given birth once Gravida 3, para 2 = woman who has been pregnant 3 times & has given birth twice

Gestation period: length of pregnancy (about 40 weeks)
For the first 8 weeks following conception, the baby is called an embryo
After 8 week of pregnancy, the baby is called a fetus


Placenta: organ that forms in the womb during pregnancy
Allows for the exchange of nutrients and waste products between the mother and the baby
Secretes the hormone human chorionic gonadotropin (HCG) at the start of pregnancy (detected by pregnancy tests)
Stimulates the release of estrogen and progesterone
Made of chorion (outer layer) and amnion (inner layer)
Umbilical cord: lifeline between the mother and baby
Amniotic sac: fluid-filled sac that protects the fetus



Hormones secreted by the baby trigger labor
Pull: the uterus contracts to dilate and pull the cervix over the baby's head
The hormone oxytocin controls the contractions
The amniotic sac opens ("water breaks") during labor
Push: the uterus pushes the baby down the birth canal
Pushing usually slows down as the baby's head crowns (emerges)
Shape-shift: the mother and baby accommodate to each other's shape
Turn: the baby spontaneously turns to allow delivery of the shoulders
Breech delivery: the baby is turned around, buttocks first; must c-section
Slide: the baby & placenta slide out
The umbilical cord gradually stops pulsing and can be safely cut a few minutes after delivery
Shrink: the uterus shrinks down to prevent blood loss
Apgar score: a rating to evaluate a newborn's health on a 2-point scale
A = activity/muscle tone
P = pulse
G = grimace/reflex
A = appearance/skin color
R = respiration


The uterus gradually returns to its pre-pregnancy size
Mammary glands are stimulated to lactate (produce milk)
Lasts 6-8 weeks


Ectopic pregnancy
Embryo implants outside the uterus (usually in fallopian tube)
The pregnancy is not viable
Hyperemesis gravidarum
Extreme morning sickness
Mother in danger of dehydration
Possible causes: rising blood levels of HCG
Treatment: IV fluids, anti-nausea meds, and avoiding triggers
Gestational diabetes
High blood sugar during pregnancy
Goes back to normal after birth
Manage with insulin
Baby will not be born with diabetes; increases the risk of an extremely large baby
Pregnancy-induced hypertension (pre-eclampsia)
Severe high blood pressure and swelling of hands, face, & feet
Cause: retention of toxins in mother's system
Can lead to convulsions in mother and problems for baby if untreated
Premature birth
A birth that takes place prior to 37 weeks' gestation
Babies may have low birth weight & jaundice and may spend time in the NICU
Shoulder Dystocia
Stuck shoulders
Baby fails to rotate to allow shoulders to ease out or baby is just too large for the mother's pelvis and gets stuck
Can cause excessive tearing of mother's tissues & bleeding, injury to baby's shoulder and brain damage (due to lack of oxygen)
Placenta previa
The placenta is abnormally positioned so that is covers the cervix
Blocks baby's exit from the womb
Requires surgical delivery of baby
Meconium aspiration syndrome
Meconium: baby's first feces
If meconium is passed in utero and the baby breathes it in during delivery, it can cause breathing issues for the baby
Fetal distress
Baby's heart rate becomes erratic or slows down


Amniocentesis
A needle is used to withdraw a sample of amniotic fluid from around the fetus
Fluid is sent for genetic testing
Continuous fetal monitoring
If mother is anesthetized, she cannot cannot provide feedback about the progress of her labor or the baby’s condition
An electronic fetal monitor is strapped to the mother's abdomen
Electrodes may also be screwed into the baby's scalp
Assisted delivery
Forceps or a vacuum are applied to the baby’s head
The baby is manually pulled out of the birth canal
Episiotomy
The mother's perineum is cut
Obstetricians do this in complicated births (fetal distress, breech, shoulder dystocia, excessively large baby) and c-sections
Obstetricians also used to (and some still do) this routinely to “prevent tearing” – new research shows natural tears heal better
The incision must be surgically repaired
Cesarean section
Surgical delivery of baby
The "husband stitch" A medically unnecessary and harmful surgical procedure in which one/more additional sutures than necessary are used to repair a woman's perineum after being torn during childbirth Its purpose was to tighten the opening of the vagina for the pleasure of the woman's partner during intercourse It can cause a lifetime of pain and is not an approved medical procedure It is considered malpractice without the woman's consent in Canada

item.title: Basic Word Structure
item.description:
Medical terminology describes:
parts of the body
locations of the body
bodily functions
surgical/clinical procedures
diseases
measurements, medical instruments, etc.
Term analysis: an organized approach to learning medical terms
Medical terms are made up of 3 word elements:
11 Roots: the main part of the word; often refers to a body part
13 Prefixes: the first part of the word that makes it more specific
12 Suffixes: the end of the word
Not all words have all 3 word elements
Word with all 3 elements Hypothyroidism Prefix: hypo- (low/deficient)
Root: thryroid/o (thyroid gland)
Suffix: -ism (condition) Meaning: condition where someone has a deficient thyroid gland
Word with no root Aphasia Prefix: a- (without or not)
Root: n/a
Suffix: -phasia (speech) Meaning: difficulty with language/speech
Word with no prefix Cardiology Prefix: n/a
Root: cardi/o (heart)
Suffix: -ology (study of) Meaning: study of the heart
Word with 2 roots Cardiomyopathy Prefix: n/a
Root 1: cardi/o
Root 2: my/o
Suffix: -pathy (disease) Meaning: disease of the heart muscle

Combining form: a root + a combining vowel
Combining vowel: usually "o," but sometimes "i" (as in pelv/i) or "e"
Purpose is to aid in pronunciation when:
Root + root
Cardiomyopathy or osteoarthritis
Root + suffix when the suffix begins with a consonant
Cardiology (cardi/o + -logy)

item.title: Types of Law
item.description:
A set of rules created by a society that governs the conduct of its members, is recognized and enforced by the government, and includes a punishment if broken
The rule of law:
No one is above the law; everyone is subject to the law and treated equally
The court system settles disputes; we don't take matters into our own hands



Tells you what the rules are

Public law deals with issues that affect society as a whole
Private law deals with issues that affect private individuals or organizations


Tells you how to apply or enforce those rules.
Substantive vs. procedural Substantive: You are charged with theft Procedural:
Police must have reasonable grounds to search and arrest you
Police must inform you of your legal rights and give you a chance to contact counsel
Police must file a charge specifying what you are accused of
Police must release you or bring you before a judge or justice of the peace in order to speak to bail
The trial must occur within a reasonable timeframe
The trial must adhere to certain procedures and strict rules of evidence

item.description:
The highest law (all other laws have to follow it)

Sets out the division of powers (different levels of government have authority to pass laws)
Contains the Charter of Rights and Freedoms (outlines the rights of individuals that the government cannot infringe upon within reasonable limits)
Fundamental freedoms

Mobility rights
Legal rights

Language rights


Made by elected lawmakers ("government-made law")
A law becomes statute when it's passed (e.g., driving age)



Based on past court decisions
Decisions/rulings made by judges can set precedents, but it is flexible; judges can set new legal doctrines
Stare decisis: the rule of precedent
Lower courts must follow the decisions of higher courts (decisions are binding)
Courts of equal rank should try to follow decisions (decisions are persuasive)
Public & private law in Canada All of Canada follows the same public law (based on English law) Quebec follows different private law (i.e., statute and common law) in the Civil Code of Quebec

Trial courts

Circumstances of the case
Prior criminal record
Public interest
Impact on victims (testify twice, long delay, etc.)
Classifications of common offences Indictable offences: murder, robbery Summary conviction offences: causing a disturbance Hybrid offence: sexual interference, theft (indictable if stolen goods worth >$5,000; summary conviction if worth <$5,000)

item.title: Guilty Plea and Sentencing Procedure
item.description:
Determination of guilt
Determination of punishment



Denunciation
To publicly condemn the unlawful conduct
Deterrence
- General - discourage the general public from committing the same/similar offence in the future
- Specific - discourage the accused from committing the same/similar offence in the future
Other purposes:
Separate offenders from society if necessary
Rehabilitate offenders
Provide reparations for harm done
Promote a sense of responsibility in offenders to victims and their community


A sentence must be proportionate to the gravity of the offence and the degree of responsibility of the offender
The judge must attempt to impose a penalty which balances the competing interests of both the guilty party and society
Sentence should be increased/reduced to account for relevant aggravating/mitigating circumstances relating to the offence/offender
Statutory aggravating factors:
Hate crime
Domestic violence
Victim under 18
Abused position of trust/authority
Gang/criminal organization
Terrorism
Similar sentences for similar offenders for similar offences committed in similar circumstances
Combined sentence should not be unduly long or harsh
All available sanctions other than imprisonment that are reasonable in the circumstances should be considered (particularly indigenous offenders)
Sentencing is an individualized process within the framework of the Criminal Code and precedent


A judge/justice should craft a sentence that embraces traditional indigenous sentencing principles where possible
The more serious the offence, the less emphasis placed on these considerations
R. v. Gladue, [1999] 1 SCR 688
R. v. Ipeelee, [2012] 1 SCR 433


Sentencing hearing
Can be quick and happen right after verdict
OR adjourned to a later time/date
After submissions of counsel, there are also be:
Order from the judge for a presentence report to help them understand the individual circumstances of the offender/offence
Victim impact statements
Viva voce evidence
Exhibits


Imprisonment/custodial sentence
One of the most severe sentences
Sentencing judge is required to use less restrictive sanctions if possible
Provincial institution: for sentences < 2 years
Federal institution: for sentences > 2 years
Imprisonment for life
First-degree murder = automatic life - no eligibility for 25 years
Second-degree murder = automatic life - no eligibility for 10-25 years (jury may make recommendation for parole ineligibility period)
Other offences = no edibility for parole for 7 years
Intermittent sentence: term of imprisonment typically served on weekends
Conditional sentence (house arrest): option for sentences 2 years or less; served in the community
Concurrent sentences: sentences imposed for separate crimes are served at the same time
Consecutive sentences: sentences imposed for separate crimes are served one after the other
Fine
Probation
Discharge
Dangerous offender
Long-term offender


Conditional release of a prisoner before they've served their full custodial sentence
To promote successful reintegration into society
Remainder of sentence served in the community under supervision
When a prisoner is eligible for release, the Parole Board of Canada will assess the risk posed and make a decision on whether to grant parole
Temporary release
Day parole
Full parole
Statutory release
If parole is breached = fine is imposed


May be imposed for any offence which doesn't have a minimum term of imprisonment
If the accused doesn't have the money on hand, they can
Ask for time to pay
OR work off the fine under the fine option program
Deemed days: a prescribed number of days the accused will spend in jail if they don't pay the fine (proportionate to the amount of the fine)


Where an accused pleads guilty or is found guilty of an offence, the judge may choose to suspend the passing of sentence for a period of time
Conviction entered
Accused is placed on probation for a period of time and required to abide by conditions
If probation order is followed successfully, no further punishment
If probation order is breached
Brought back to court and sentenced on the original charge
and/or charged with criminal offence of breach of probation



Community Service
Work done in and for the benefit of the community
Done to pay off a monetary fine or as a term of probation
Restitution
Payment made by the accused to cover actual expenses resulting from the commission of the offence to the victim (broken window, slashed tire...)


Where an accused pleads guilty or is found guilty of an offence, the judge may grant a discharge instead of entering a conviction
Must be in the best interests of the accused and not contrary to public interest
2 types of discharge:
Absolute discharge
Deemed not to have been convicted
No criminal record
Conditional discharge
Accused is placed on probation for a period of time and required to abide by conditions
If probation order is followed successfully, the discharge becomes absolute
If probation order is breached
Brought back to court and sentenced on the original charge
and/or charged with criminal offence of breach of probation
Reminder about criminal records If accused is given a discharge = no criminal record If accused is given a suspended sentence = they have a criminal record


Dangerous, violent, and sexual predators who are likely to reoffend in the future
Crown can make an application after conviction has been entered, and there would follow a lengthy sentencing hearing with viva voce evidence including psychological evidence
If Crown is successful = accused is given an indeterminate term of imprisonment
Remain in custody indefinitely
Until the risk to reoffend no longer exists


Used where an individual doesn't meet the criteria for a DO designation but has been convicted of a serious personal injury offence and is considered likely to re-offend
If declared a LO, the accused will be sentenced to a specified term of incarceration
Upon release, accused will be subject to a supervision order in the community for a max of 10 years


Victim fine surcharge
Monetary penalty paid by accused in addition to any other sentence
DNA order
Mandatory for primary designated offences
Discretionary for secondary designated offences
Firearms and weapons prohibition
Sometimes mandatory
Sex Offenders Information Registry (SOIRA) order
Sometimes mandatory


Canvassing Section 606(1.1)
Accused is entering the guilty plea voluntarily,
understands the consequences of pleading guilty, and
understands that the Court is not bound by any argument made by counsel
Joint submission

The judge is not bound to accept a joint submission

If the accused pleads guilty, there is no need for a trial


Disputes the facts in a material way?
Offers a defence?
Doesn't acknowledge the requirements of Section 606(1.1)?
Appears to be of unsound mind?
Then...

Guilty plea is not struck
Not guilty plea is entered on their behalf
Matter is set down for trial in front of a different judge/justice


An offence whose elements are encompassed by a greater offence
You can't commit the greater offence without also committing the lesser included offence(s)
Some lesser included offences Theft + assault = robbery Assault + possession of a weapon = assault with a weapon Break and enter + theft = break and enter and commit theft

item.title: Presentation of Evidence
item.description:
The accused is presumed innocent
Crown has the burden of proof
So...

Crown must present their case first
Call witnesses to testify
Enter exhibits
Accused has the option to call a case (they don't have to prove anything)
Formal commitment to tell the truth should be binding upon one's conscience
Oath: includes a statement to a high power based upon one's religion
Affirmation: does not include a religious statement



Cross-examination is limited to issues arising from examination-in-chief (direct examination)
Re-examination is limited to issues arising from cross-examination
Re-cross-examination is limited to issues arising from re-examination
Leading question: a question which suggests the answer
Only permitted in cross-examination/re-cross examination
A leading question Q What color was the vehicle?
vs.
Q Was the vehicle a black Ford SUV?


Tangible items
Put before the trier of fact
To be considered in arriving at a verdict
Exhibits for identification
Not completely identified (who, what, where) and/or
Continuity has not been established
Full exhibit
Completely identified (who, what, where) and
Continuity has been established (unbroken chain of custody/proper preservation)
Exhibits for identification
Only full exhibits can be relied upon (considered) by the trier of fact

item.title: Preliminary Inquiry Procedure
item.description:
Pretrial hearings held in Provincial Court
For offences proceeding by Indictment where the max penalty is 14 years or more
To determine if there is sufficient evidence for the case to proceed to trial in the Court of King's Bench
The accused may waive the preliminary inquiry with consent of the Crown
The accused will be ordered to stand trial without the need for further evidence
Direct indictment: allows Crown to bypass preliminary inquiry and proceed straight to trial
Only in rare and exceptional circumstances because it takes away the accused's right to a preliminary inquiry
Extremely long/complex cases
To protect ongoing police investigations
May cause significant harm to a witness (psychological or physical)
A preliminary was commenced but not concluded
There is deliberate delay of proceedings
Requires written consent of the Attorney General



This case established rules about disclosure as it relates to a fair trial
Full disclosure: Crown must share all evidence (even evidence that could help defence and harm their own case) in a timely manner so as to let defence prepare for trial
Before this, preliminary inquiries were held so that defence could learn about the Crown's case


Do you already have enough disclosure?
Do you want evidence "on the record"?
Will a preliminary inquiry help the defense understand the evidence and witnesses better for trial?
Could a preliminary inquiry help the Crown find and fix weaknesses in their case?
Could the accused face new charges arising out of the evidence?
Can a preliminary inquiry help to settle the case?
Can the client afford both a preliminary inquiry and a trial?


Crown only needs to establish a prima facie case
There must be some evidence on each of the essential elements of the crime
Any doubt in the mind of the Provincial Court judge during a preliminary inquiry is resolved in favour of the Crown
How sufficient evidence works IF the evidence called by the Crown is believed,
COULD the accused be found guilty? Yes - accused is ordered to stand trial
No - accused is discharged



All prospective witnesses are excluded from the courtroom until their testimony is done at trial
This is done before the commencement of a trial or preliminary inquiry
On the motion of one of the parties or the Court (the judge)


Evidence taken at a preliminary inquiry shall not be published or broadcast or transmitted in any way until:
The accused is discharged or preliminary or
The trial in Court of King's Bench has ended
Reasons for ban:
Reading/watching media coverage may color a witness's testimony
Media coverage could influence/bias potential jurors
What if a witness is in the courtroom when they should have been excluded? They may still testify BUT the judge may place less weight on their evidence


Submissions made by counsel are not evidence


To help the trier of fact understand the evidence to be presented
Outlines the facts that they intend to prove
Summarizes the theory of their case


To persuade the trier of fact to decide in your favor
Emphasizes evidence favorable to their case
Emphasizes weaknesses in the other party's case

confidence is key

item.title: Translate Options
item.description:
Case CAT analyzes untranslates that contain characters you tend to drag or characters that are missing that you tend to drop in order to find a match to a steno outline in a dictionary being used to translate the file.
If Case CAT finds a match, the translated text will be surrounded by Drag/Drop Being and End format symbols.
For example, you tend to drag your final L. "Grate" is in your Personal Dictionary. You write GRAEULT. The untranslate will appear and "grate."
Specify the characters that you tend to drag and/or drop in Drag/Drop Analysis Details.
While editing, if Drag/Drop Analysis has translated the untranslate correctly, you can press Enter to confirm the translation.
To enable: Tools menu in Manage Jobs screen, Options, Translate, Translate, Input tab, select Drag/Drop Analysis, select Details, add keys you tend to drag and drop by clicking on the keyboard diagram (e.g., -L is commonly dragged)
TrueStroke Drag/Drop Analysis
If using:

Luminex via USB/Wi-Fi connection
Diamante via USB/Wi-Fi connection
Wave via USB connection
Cast CAT analyzes untranslates during realtime translation using TrueStroke data located in the Steno X-subfile to match a steno outline in a dictionary being used to translate.
TrueStroke Drag/Drop has priority over Drag/Drop Analysis if both options are selected.
While editing, if TrueStroke Drag/Drop has translated the untranslate correctly, you can press Enter to confirm the translation.
To enable: Tools menu in Manage Jobs screen, Options, Translate, Translate, Input tab, select TrueStroke Drag/Drop Analysis. No other action required.

When active, Case CAT translate, by default, steno outlines accidentally stroked with a dragged letter -G, -S, or -D as a suffix letter tucked inside a steno outline.
Suffix Drag/Phrase Maker allows you to select whether dragged steno should be considered a suffix or a word.
Suffix Drag
Suffix Drag applies the suffix strokes -G, -S, -Z, or -D to single-stroke untranslates when the dragged letter is the last character in the outline.
The translated text will be surrounded by Suffix Drag Begin and End format symbols.
For example, "blog" is defined in your Personal Dictionary, but the steno stroke BLOGD is not. The untranslate will appear as "blogged."
Set Suffix Drag Options by clicking the Details button. Use -S, -Z, or both for a plural suffix. Tuckable suffixes are permitted. For example, the untranslated SLAOEGT would translate as "sleeting."
Phrase Maker
For example, let's say the steno stroke TPH-GT is not defined in the dictionary. However, you have TPH defined as "in" and -GT is set as a "word" type in your Suffix Drag/Phrase Maker Options as the word "this."
With the Word option in Suffix Drag/Phrase Maker, you can have TPH-GT translate as "in this" even though it is not defined in your dictionary as a single stroke.
Suffix Drag/Phrase Maker only applies to one-stroke words in which steno characters can be added as a suffix. Suffix Drag/Phrase Maker options allow you to add other steno characters you want Case CAT to consider a suffix.
The Plural Endings Options allow you to use the final S, final Z, or both for plural endings. To confirm the combined words are spelled correctly, set the Suffix Drag/Phrase Maker Spell Check option for the steno outline.
If Spell Check is active, Case CAT checks the newly combined word to confirm the combined word is spelled correctly. If a correctly spelled word is not found, Case CAT tries the next possible suffix to find an actual word. This may result in a correctly spelled word but not the word intended. If Case CAT does not find a correctly spelled word with an added suffix, the steno outline remains an untranslate and no conversion takes place. The Spellchecked option has no influence on phrases created by Suffix Drag/Phrase Maker.
If also using TrueStroke Drag/Drop or Drag/Drop Analysis, TrueStroke Drag/Drop and then Drag/Drop Analysis takes priority.
To enable: Tools menu in Manage Jobs screen, Options, Translate, Input tab, select Suffix Drag/Phrase Maker, select Details, add a new entry by clicking on the blank row at the bottom of the list
Some common phrasing:

Delete Repeated Q/A/C
If multiple Qs, As, or Colloquy paragraphs (with the same name) are written on right after another with no text in between, Case CAT will automatically delete the empty paragraphs so only one paragraph displays.
For example, if you write the steno outline defined as <Question> five times in a row without text, only one Q will display in the transcript.
Use Smart Quotes
By selecting this option, you only need one dictionary definition for a quotation mark. When you write the steno defined as a quotation mark (") the first time in a paragraph, Case CAT inserts an opening quote. When you write that same steno outline again, Case CAT inserts a closing quote.
If you wrote the steno defined as quotation mark once and did not write it again to close the quotation, Case CAT automatically puts a closing quote at the end of the current paragraph style
For CACR students, this option should be selected.
Use Smart Parentheses
By selecting this option, you only need one dictionary definition for a parenthesis or bracket. When you write the steno defined as the open parenthesis or bracket the first time, Case CAT inserts an open parenthesis or bracket. When you write the same steno outline a second time, Case CAT inserts a closed parenthesis or bracket.
If you wrote the steno defined as open parenthesis or bracket once but did not write it again, Case CAT automatically inserts the closed parenthesis or bracket at the end of the current paragraph.

item.title: Fingerspelling
item.description:
Fingerspelling involves writing a word one letter at a time using alphabets on your steno writer instead of writing a word with phonetic outlines. When you hear a word that isn't in your dictionary, you will need to spell it out.
Sound cumbersome? It certainly can be and often is. The good news is that it is a skill that can be practiced and even perfected, and it can become a valuable tool in your realtime career.
While fingerspelling is not a substitute for a solid, conflict-free theory and a good workign set of prefixes, suffixes, and word roots, it is an excellent way to handle the occasional oddball word or name that will will inevitably hear on the job.
Once you've determined how you will write your fingerspelling alphabet, it's time to practice it. Just as you needed to drill yourself on shorthand speed, you probably will also need to do the same with your fingerspelling skills. Practice at home with random words picked out of the dictionary; experiment with it while practicing for accuracy.
Start with small words and work up to longer ones. Work to achieve a steady rhythm as you spell, rather than frantic, jerky bursts. You'll be surprised how quickly that word can come out, if you don't panic! Try to think of fingerspelling as just another bunch of outlines and jump right in.

You already have three alphabets in your personal dictionary. Make entries for the fourth alphabet, lowercase letters with parentheses.

item.title: Brief It! and Live Suggestions
item.description:
What does it do?
A realtime feature that suggests conflict-free brief forms for words and phrases as you are writing. When you write three or more steno strokes, Case CAT generates a brief form or reminds you of an existing brief form and displays it in the Brief It dialog pane.
For example?
You have written "personal chequing account" twice. Case CAT suggests P*K as a brief, which appears in the Brief It pane on a yellow background. You like the suggestions and begin writing P*K, and it translates as "personal chequing account."
You write "joint account" out. Case CAT reminds you that J-KT is a brief in your Personal Dictionary. The reminder appears in the Brief It pane on a green background.
How do I do it?
Enabled Brief It during realtime translation:

Press Ctrl t to open the Translate dialog box and press Alt p (Options).
Click the Realtime tab.
In the Realtime Aids section, select Brief It.
In a realtime file, open the Brief It pane by pressing Alt v, e, t (View, Panes, Brief It). When you want to use a suggested brief, simply write the steno.


What does it do?
A realtime feature that automatically offers translation suggestions when an untranslate displays in the transcript. You have the option to ignore, replace, or define the suggestion from the writer during realtime or with a keyboard command.
For example?
You misstroke and write SHRAOUR. In the Brief It pane, "sure" is the first and correct suggestion. You write a realtime command from your writer to replace the untranslate.
How do I do it?
Enable Live Suggestions during realtime translation:

Press Ctrl t to to open the Translate dialog box and press Alt p (Options).
Click the Realtime tab.
In the Realtime Aids section, select Live Suggestions.
Add the Live Suggestions realtime commands to your Personal Dictionary.
In System Files, open the Realtime Commands Dictionary.
Select each of the {Replace With LS#} and {Define With LS#} entries. Right mouse click and copy to your Personal Dictionary.
In your Personal Dictionary, modify the steno as desired. If you select to display more than three Live Suggestions in your options, create new dictionary entries and LS4 and LS5.
In a realtime file, open the Brief It pane by pressing Alt v, e, t (View, Panes, Brief It).
Write the steno stroke for the {Replace With LS#} or {Define With LS#} command that corresponds to the correct Live Suggestion.
Tips and Tricks
At least four translated words or phrases need to be written after the untranslate before a Live Suggestion will be offered.
Only one Live Suggestion is offered at a time. The suggestions display until the next untranslate is written.
Live Suggestions appear on a light blue background in the Brief It pane.
One you select a Live Suggestion, the background color turns gray and the remaining suggestions appear crossed out. To hide suggestions that were not selected, deselect the Rejected option in the Brief It pane filter options.
You can also right click a Live Suggestion in the Brief It pane and select Replace with this Suggestion or Define this Suggestion. Double clicking a Live Suggestion will replace the untranslate.

Modify Brief It Options

From the All Options dialog box, under Edit Panes, select Brief It.
From the Brief It pane, click the Options icon.
From Manage Jobs, press Alt t, o, e, b (Tools, Options, Edit, Brief It).
From Edit, press Alt t, o, Enter, b (Tools, Options, Pane Options, Brief It).
Show Phonetic Steno
Check this box to have Brief It display steno as it sounds. For example, the suggested brief for "Yoko Ono" would appear as Y*O as opposed to KWR*O.
When Show Phonetic Steno is selected, steno in the Cat Scratch Text/Steno section will also display phonetically.
Only Suggest 1 Stroke Briefs
Check this box to have Brief It suggest only one-stroke Suggested briefs. By default, Brief It always suggests a one-stroke brief with the asterisk before suggesting a two-stroke brief.
Selecting this option also affects Reminder and Personal briefs. For example, you write "neurotoxicity" in four or five strokes. When this option is active, Brief It does not remind you that you have TPHAOUR/TOX in your Personal Dictionary as a two-stroke entry.
Write Twice to Define
Brief It, by default, automatically creates a J-Define or a K-Define the first time you use a Suggested brief. Checking this box requires you to consecutively write a brief twice before Brief It creates a J-Define or K-Define. You may want to use this option to try a Suggested brief before making it a definition.
For example, Brief It suggests A*BT for "Abbott Labs." If the Write twice to Define option is active, you would need to write A*BT/A*BT to have Case CAT create the global. Once defined, you write A*BT for "Abbott Labs" for the remainder of the job.
Define to Case Dictionary
Check this box to place a Suggested brief in the case dictionary once it is written. If the current job is not in a case, then the brief is placed in the job dictionary.
Personal/Reminders Only
Check this box to display only Reminder and Personal briefs in the Brief It dialog pane. Suggested briefs are not created.
1 Stroke Reminders for 2 Strokes
Check this box to have Brief It offer one-stroke Reminders or Personal briefs when writing two-stroke entries. For example, if you write "I don't" in two strokes and there is a one-stroke version in your Personal Dictionary, Brief It shows the one-stroke brief as a Reminder.
Auto Open Brief It
Check this box to automatically display the Brief It dialog pane when starting realtime. By default, this option is selected.
Send Used Briefs to Cat Scratch
Check this box to automatically send a Suggested brief you use to the Steno/Text section of the Cat Scratch dialog pane.
Steno Include/Exclude
Displays the Brief It Options table where you can modify the Require and Exclude entries.
The Require entry contains the steno character or steno combination to be included in every Suggested brief. There is only one Require entry.
Exclude entries contain steno characters or steno combinations to exclude from every Suggested brief. You can have multiple Exclude entries.
Personal Briefs
Personal Briefs are entries which are created prior to translation and are stored in the Briefs.txt file in the System Files case. A default Briefs.txt file exists for each user.
Creating entries in the Briefs.txt file allows you to store words and phrases along with the brief form without placing them in a dictionary. For example, you got some good ideas for briefs from an article in the JCR but you're not certain you want to put them in your Personal Dictionary.
Common Words
The CommonWords.txt file contains a list of words the Brief It does not consider when looking for words and phrases for brief suggestions. Is a phrase is written that begins or ends with a word from the CommonWords.txt file, no brief is suggested. For example, by default the word "about" is in the CommonWords.txt file. When a phrase is written that begins or ends with the word "about" and no Reminder or Personal brief exists for the word or phrase, Brief It does not suggest a brief.
Allow Briefs with Numbers
Check this box to have Brief It offer suggestions for repeated dollar amounts or addresses.
An additional option is available in the Steno Include/Exclude list where a Required for Numbers entry is available. For example if the Required for Numbers entry is EU and you write 23925 several times throughout the transcript, Brief It might suggest 23EU9. (EU is the default steno entry.)
Be default, the following number/steno key combinations are excluded in the Brief Include/Exclude Options: #1S, #2K, #3W, #4R, #6-R, #7-B, #8-G, #9-S
To prevent any number bar number from being suggested, press Ctrl + i and type # and press Enter.
Allow Double First Syllable
Check this box to have Brief It offer the first syllable of the text (single word or phrase) written twice as the suggested brief. For example, the word "fluorescent" is used multiple times in the transcript. You write "fluorescent" in multiple strokes and Brief It suggests TPHROR/TPHROR.
When you have both Write Twice to Define and Allow Double First Syllable options selected, if the suggested brief has two identical strokes, Brief It will behave as if "Write Twice to Define" option was not active. In other words, you do not need to write the brief four times to use it. If the brief is one stroke or is multiple (not identical) strokes, briefs will need to be written twice to be used.
No Nag List
Check this box to designate words or phrases that should no longer be offered as a suggestion or a reminder. For example, you have the phrase "of the" in your Personal Dictionary, but sometimes you write it in two strokes. You do not want Brief It to remind you of the phrase.
From the Brief It pane, right click an entry or highlight multiple entries and then right click. Select Send Text to No Nag List. Alternatively, select No Nag List in Brief It options and type the text portion of the entry.

Insert Oops when replacing with a live suggestion
Select to add an <Oops> format symbol (category 10) whenever you select to replace an untranslate with a Live Suggestion. This enables you to scan to Live Suggestion replacements and confirm change. You can also view each instance in the Hotspots pane.
Number of Suggestions
Select how many suggestions should be offered in the Brief It pane. Select from 2 to 5 suggestions. The default number of suggestions is 3.
Dictionary Defines go to
Select the destination dictionary you want a defined suggestion to go to when using the {Define With LS#} commands. When this option is set to case dictionary and the transcript is not in a case, entries will go to the job dictionary.
Show "translated" text as first Live Suggestions
By default, this option is active and Drag/Drop, Suffix Drag, and phonetically translated text will be the first choice in the Live Suggestion list.

item.title: Phonetic Translation
item.description:
What is it?
When active, Case CAT phonetically translates steno outlines when no match is found in any dictionary used for translation. This prevents the display of untranslates on the realtime screen.
Put another way:
The Phonetic Table contains steno outlines and phonetic text equivalents. When the Advanced Translate option, Phonetic untranslates display as words is set to No and you select the Phonetic Translation option or use the Toggle Phonetic Mode during realtime, steno outlines normally displayed as untranslates translate phonetically based on the text equivalent entry in the Phonetic Table and Suggested briefs based on your Brief It options.
Example
The proceedings include the name Jaymes. If no dictionary entry for the steno SKWRAEUPLZ exists, the steno outline displays as an untranslate. Using the Phonetic Table, each steno combination matches to the text equivalent. The result displays as JAIMZ in the transcript instead of SKWRAEUPLZ, as shown:
SKWR  = J
A = A
EU = I
PL  = M
-Z = Z
When the Advanced Translate option “Phonetic untranslates display as words” is set to Yes, Case CATalyst use a phonetic algorithmic logic to determine the intended pronunciation. The Phonetic Table is not used.
How do I do it?
In the Input tab of Translation Options, you can have Phonetic Translation automatically turn on when you start a realtime file.
Alternatively, you can add the Toggle Phonetic Mode entry to your personal dictionary and turn it on or off directly from your machine.
{Toggle Phonetic Mode} = TOPB/TOPB
How does it work?
The phonetic table in System Files contains steno outlines and phonetic text equivalents. Steno outlines translate phonetically based on the text equivalent in the phonetic table.
/PHROFRP = Plomp
Phonetic untranslates display as words - Yes/No
Select Yes to phonetically translate single stroke untranslates during realtime using algorithmic logic to determine the intended pronunciation. Case CATalyst bases the logic on Stenograph Theory and the WinterTree Spell Check, Stedman’s Medical and Black’s Legal wordlists to create a word with the most accurate spelling of the phonetically sounded word. Phonetic translation applies when no dictionary match is found in any dictionary used for translation.

item.title: RealTeam
item.description:
What is it?
It's a simultaneous editing feature which allows sharing of text, globals, and audio with one or more scopists or proofreaders while the reporter is writing realtime.
For example?
A reporter begins a realtime file and invites their scopist to join. The scopist accepts the invitation, and the realtime file opens on their computer. The scopist has access to the audio and can perform all editing functions. Any changes made by the reporter or the scopist are reflected on both systems.
What do I need?

RealTeam or Cloud Backup login
Contact information for the scopist or proofreader
Internet connection with or without a local network
Edge for Case CAT Support Plan
How do I do it?

Each participant logs in to RealTeam by selecting RealTeam Ready from the file menu/RealTeam toolbar
The reporter (host) begins a realtime file and invites each participant to the RealTeam session from the Translate dialog box/RealTeam toolbar/File menu
Each participant will hear a "ringing" sound when the invitation is received, and the Case CAT icon will flash on the Windows taskbar. The RealTeam dialog box will display the email address of the host and the path and filename where the transcript will be opened.
Once the invitation is accepted, each participant will immediately receive the entire available text file and audio file. The participants can begin editing the file.

Tips & Tricks
Open the Connected Users pane to display the status of each participant.
If you are editing right up against the realtime text, the audio playback may stop because there isn't audio available yet. Select Play Audio again after a few seconds.
If there is more than one scopist or proofreader working on the same file, one person should be designated as the team's leader and determine who is responsible for editing which portions of the job. It's recommended that each participant leave hidden text or visible notes at stopping or starting points to avoid gaps or duplication of efforts.
Additional Notes
The participant's system will adopt the file structure and naming convention as established by the host.
Settings such as page/normal view, colors, and panes display are based on the individual user settings.
Each participant's name will display on the screen to indicate their cursor location along with their current page number/location. If a participant is editing above the current text on the screen, their cursor (name) displays in the upper left-hand corner of your realtime screen. If their cursor is below the current text on the screen, their cursor displays in the lower left-hand corner of the realtime screen.
Double clicking a fellow participant's cursor position will shift your view to their position in the file.

item.title: CasePrep
item.description:
What does it do?
Enables you to quickly and thoroughly prepare for your next job. Case Prep compares transcripts and other documents against one or more dictionaries to determine which words are and are not in your dictionaries. Case Prep uses this information to

generate a Dictionary Builder List for words and phrases that are not in the selected dictionaries or your Personal Dictionary
generate a Heads Up List of words and phrases that you will want to define and possibly brief.
For example?
The RCTT lawsuit is coming to trial, and you expect daily transcript to be ordered. You are going to do some prep work so that your translation is as clean as possible. You have been provided discovery transcripts from colleagues, some on Case CAT and some on a different software. You are also planning to do some internet research about suitable soil types for construction. You run Case Prep and quickly mine the relevant information from all sources. You then create dictionary entries and generate briefs.
How do I do it?

Gather your resources. Restore Case Cat transcripts to your user. Text or PDF documents which contain helpful information can be saved anywhere on your computer.
Supported file types are Cat text files (.sgngl), Cat BCS files (.sgcap), ASCIIs (.txt), .PDFs, .PTX, and/or .XMEF
If a colleague on different CAT software provides a file in the RTF/CRE format, import the file into Case Cat.
If you are obtaining information from email or the internet, copy and paste the text into a Case Cat file.
From Manage Jobs, click Tools, Case Prep. Complete the steps as prompted in the wizard.
Tips & Tricks
You can print the contents of the Brief It pane by clicking the Printer icon on the Brief It pane.
If you want different results (one list containing phrases sorted by and one list containing words and phrases not in the dictionary sorted by words then phrases), you can run Case Prep more than once.
A Microsoft Word document can be saved as a plain .TXT file and used with Case Prep.
Phrases are generated from transcripts (.sgngl) or caption (.sgcap) files whether there is underlying steno outlines or not. ASCII and PDF files will only generate words, so it may be preferable to paste the contents of an ASCII or PDF into a Case CAT text file.

item.title: CART Captioning
item.description:
display options may include computers, monitors, large screens, and mobile devices
we can share our speech to text display anywhere
many web conferencing platforms allow captioners to provide captions for online meetings (host must assign closed captioning privileges to the captioner)
one to one captioner to client experience is when a captioner sits next to the client and shares a display with the client (choose a clean layout - no line numbers, normal view, hidden menu bars, customize color, font style, and font size)

What is it?

An alternative to sharing the writer’s screen is Output to CARTView which allows the writer to display the text on a second monitor or screen.
CARTView (local display) is available in the Output To: field in the Translate dialog box. Outputting to CARTView displays a separate window which can display on your computer or you can drag the window to another monitor or computer screen. The CARTView window displays text with no toolbars or menus.
The display may be customized by changing the color of the text, background, font style and size, background transparency, line spacing and the position of the window. You can save the CARTView settings to the Alternate User Settings feature.
Editing changes to the realtime screen are reflected on the CARTView screen. If the CARTView window is displayed on another monitor/computer, you can use editing features that display dialog boxes on the realtime screen without displaying the dialog boxes on the CARTView window. For example, you can use the Power Define feature to easily define from your writing machine or you can have the Brief It pane open in your software.
The Case CATalyst CARTView Settings Icon is available in the Windows System Tray. When selected, the icon displays the CARTView screen settings such as font, transparency, color, etc. The system tray icon makes it easy to control the CARTView settings when you do not have instant access to the CARTView window.
For example, let’s say you are in the back of a large convention room with CARTView displaying on a large screen in the front of the room when you realize you need to change the color or the size of the text to make it more readable. By clicking the Case CATalyst CARTView Settings icon, you will instantly have access to the CARTView settings. No need to go to the front of the room to make adjustments.

What is it?

Parentheticals are commonplace in CART and should be used to indicate environmental sounds that may or may not be apparent to the consumer.
Style

Parentheticals should appear in title case with an open bracket, space, \<text>, space, close bracket.
Defined in the dictionary as:

\<Parenthetical>
(
\<Sticky Space>
\<Caption: KeepCaseOn>
Cheers and Applause
\<Caption: KeepCaseOff>
\<Sticky Space>
)

A parenthetical should appear independently on a new line
No punctuation is applied to the parenthetical
Note: The ( Inaudible ) parenthetical is used when the writer cannot hear what has been said and stays in line with the text

CATalyst Broadcast Captioning Suite (BCS) is designed for steno caption providers. It utilizes integrated live display and scripted program features. A variety of windowing options allow you to view your realtime translation, make corrections to the translation, preview the text that displays on the viewer’s television and organize your story scripts. Additional features include the ability to view your vertical notes, session selections, and the status of the captioning mode.
Click (the BCS Captioning button) on the Function Bar or click Function, Broadcast Captioning Suite (or press Alt+u, b).
Captioning Options
Caption Translate options are a group of settings that affect how CATalyst BCS translates steno outlines. You set translate options on the Options tab in the Caption Options dialog box prior to starting a session or during a captioning session using the Options feature on the Setup menu. Options settings remain the same until you change them.
There are three translate options specific to BCS.
Remove Single Empty Paragraph

Suppress the blank line generated when a steno outline with a paragraph style is followed by a stroke defined with a paragraph style at the beginning of the definition.
Replace Q&A With >>

Converts Question and Answer format symbol to chevrons (>>).
Hold Strokes

When active, steno outlines are held before displaying the translated text on the live display. CATalyst BCS holds the steno until it finds the longest dictionary match plus the specified number of additional strokes. Once a longest match is found, BCS re-translates the steno outlines to display the longest match text. If no steno is written for a specified number of seconds, then the translated text or steno on the screen displays regardless of the longest match.
For example, let's say your Longest match plus X strokes option is set to 3 and the Held for X seconds option is set to 2. You write a four-stroke word which is a longest match plus three more strokes. When the longest match plus the additional strokes are written, CATalyst pushes out the translation. If translation isn't done with the longest match, it will hold back the translation for 2 seconds. This creates a “buffer zone” to allow for corrections in the Realtime pane.

item.title: Realtime Applications
item.description:
Three areas court reporters may be asked to write realtime:

Questionings
Trials
Hearings (quasi-judicial proceedings)

each participant has a screen available to them in order to view the live transcript
transcripts are ordered on a daily copy basis (transcript is written, edited, and proofread all on the same day)
reporters often work with a team to facilitate this turnaround
primarily use wireless connections to connect all the computers using a LAN (local area network) or a WAN (wide area network)
participants can be present or remote
reporters are sometimes expected to provide devices for the live transcript feed; sometimes participants bring their own device
realtime reporting is verbatim
The second type of realtime is CART

no opportunity to interrupt the speaker
generally, no editing and no transcripts
bulk of the work is done beforehand, preparing for the job
clients may request a transcript
an additional fee should be charged
must clarify with client whether they are looking for a rough draft or a fully edited transcript
strive for verbatim to afford the same experience to hard of hearing, but paraphrasing is acceptable when necessary
The third type of realtime is broadcast captioning

output captions to an encoder at the television station through a telephone line or an internet connection
paraphrasing is necessary when speech is too fast (audience wouldn't be able to read fast enough to keep up)

item.description:
It's about influence...

Show humility and set a good example
True leadership is when people follow you willingly, not because they have to
And making things better
Good leaders help improve situations and people by
Making better decisions
Reducing conflicts
Providing clarity
Offering support or challenges as needed


It’s a choice you can make
You can lead from anywhere, regardless of your position
Lead yourself first before leading others
Collaboration is key in leadership
Anyone can learn to be a leader
Vision is important A clear vision can guide and motivate you and your team, helping everyone see possibilities instead of challenges
Values shape leadership
Your core values drive how you behave and make decisions
Reflect on how you live these values and how they influence your leadership
Emotional intelligence matters Great leaders understand their own emotions and those of others, allowing them to build strong relationships and manage conflicts effectively
Building relationships Simple acts like being punctual, showing gratitude, and taking responsibility help create strong connections with others
Lead with possibility Good leaders inspire others by sharing a vision and fostering a sense of possibility, making everyone feel empowered to contribute


Formal learning: Take classes or read books
Experience: Practice new skills in real-life situations
Reflection: Take time to think about your actions and their impact

item.title: Communication
item.description:
“Seek to understand before being understood.”
Steven Covey
Use empathic listening as a base character to inspire openness and trust,
Listen through their frame of reference.
Diagnose before you prescribe.
By judging first, you will never fully understand.


Maintain self-awareness
Be aware of emotions and motives
Are you being judgmental or too opinionated
Self-Regulation
Emotional stability and information processing in difficult situations. Anger, frustration, grief get in the way of effective communication. Use proper tone.
Empathy
Active listening
It is important to be receptive to feedback
Learn and adapt to change


It is all the non-verbal communication we make – both conscious and unconscious.
Some studies suggest that only 7% of our judgments are based on what we actually say. These studies were usually taken when the body language was disagreeing with what was being said.
People believe far more by what they see than by what they hear.
You can change your body language to show empathy and to influence someone by slowing down your movements or taking away any unintended aggressive body language of your own.
You can learn to relax, calm and excite other people purely by the way you hold yourself, the way you move and the way you interact.
Aggressive body language
Hands on hips

Invading personal space, too close
Aggressive gesturing (finger pointing)

Overly firm handshake

Leaning away

Looking around the room
Looking at watch
Drumming fingers

Rubbing face
Open & interested body language
Firm handshake

On the same level
Confident stance
Confident, chosen gestures
Showing interest (head not, slight lean in)


Clear and concise expression of thoughts •Articulate, correct use of language, expressive
Makes good eye contact with others while speaking
Well-organized, complete, and courteous presentation of thoughts

Work begins before the conversation itself (mental preparation)
Courage, patience, confidence, vision success, reframe negatives
The approach
The manner in which you engage can tip the conversation to success.
Empathy: Seek to understand before being understood.
After you heard the other side, react with empathy, share information and your point of view, and turn the conversation back to the other person.
Collaboration, partnering, win/win

Maintain their self-esteem and yours.

item.title: The Interview
item.description:
An opportunity for an employer to assess you and your skills against their requirements for the job and the company.
For you to assess if this is where you want to work – the type of work and the company.
Preparing
3R’s: Research, Research, Research
Check out the firm website.
Use practical training as an opportunity to assess a firm.
Talk to someone who works there: firm owner, supervisor, court reporter
Caution – if you phone or Zoom:
Make sure person has time to spend.
Ask specific questions – be prepared.
Don’t try to sell yourself.
Prepare your own “interview” questions
Prepare responses to questions
Don’t have “canned” or textbook answers
3 P’s: practice, practice, practice
Obtain feedback
Think about how you will dress, present yourself and be remembered
Interview Types
Depends on level of position and size of organization)

One-on-one (firm owner / supervisor)
Panel (firm owner, supervisor, and/or court reporter)
One or two-stage
- Could start with a panel and move to one-on-one.
Sparkle and Shine The First 30 Seconds

“The first 30 seconds of a job interview are crucial.” – Ollie Stevenson
Based on experiences of real-life people.
“The interviewer makes an immediate overall judgment about you within the first five seconds, and the next 25 seconds are spent checking the chemistry and verifying the initial impression.”
Decisions often made in the first few minutes.
First Impressions
Handling nervousness: breathing exercise, visualization, and positive self-talk
Arrive 10 minutes early
Make an impression on everybody, including the receptionist and other staff
How to Handle Early Moments
Project the image that fits the job you are going after.
Make eye contact, smile, and trust your gut reactions.
Introduce yourself in a courteous manner.
Have a firm handshake. (COVID warning)
Not too eager; not too nervous.
Just be yourself.
Remember: People prefer to do business with those they like.
Dance their dance. If they sit, you sit. If they joke, you smile.
The more research you’ve done on the company before the interview will help your “chemistry” with the Interview.
Within five minutes the interviewers can tell how the interview will go.
Answering Employer's Questions
Make eye contact
Use S.T.A.R. method (Situation, Task, Activities, Result)
Be positive and professional – i.e. do not criticize former employers or staff
DO NOT LIE OR EXAGERRATE
- Body language will generally give you away
Verbal Communication
Speak clearly so that the interviewer can easily hear you.
Use good grammar and appropriate vocabulary and avoid slang.
Eg. Yeah, you guys, like, you know, whatever, hey, et cetera.
Practice changing bad habits (self-awareness).
Professional tone.
Sound positive – don’t use words like “think” or “guess.”
Non-Verbal Communication
90 percent of what we say comes from body language; 10 percent from what we say.
Positive and relaxed body language
Good posture
Good eye contact, include everyone present
Smile
Open posture; placement of hands
Use natural hand movements; not distracting.
Avoid fidgeting or distracting mannerisms.
Listening and Responding Skills
Listen to the question and do not interrupt.
Ask the interviewer for clarification if needed.
Think about your answer. You do not have to answer immediately after a question is asked. Take your time.
Answer the question briefly, but with enough information to fully answer the question.
Use a conversational tone.
Unassertive words (hesitant, fills interview with doubts):

I’ll think about it.
I’ll try.
Maybe
I’m not sure.
Yes, but
I don’t know.
Aggressive words (overbearing):
That was a stupid question.
Who do you think you are?
Well, have I got the job or not?
No sweat.
Disclaimers:
I’m sorry, but…
You may not believe this but…
This may seem silly but…
Would you mind very much if…
Assertive words (confident):
I will or I won’t
I can or I can’t
Yes, no, or I prefer
I would like to find out (indicates your willingness)
I assure you that won’t happen
Show Enthusiasm

Do you look like someone who really wants this job?
Convince yourself before convincing an interviewer!
It may be the difference that lands you the job.
If lacking, it is time for reflection and soul-searching.
Supporting Information and Interview-Ending Behaviour
Have questions prepared when asked if you have any questions.
Extra copies of resume and application letter.
List of references and contact information.
Say “thank you” for the interview.
Appropriate ending statement depending on next steps.
Shake hands (COVID warning).
