item.title: Taxes, Expense Accounts, and GST
item.description:
If the reporter's relationship with the firm is that of a subcontractor, the reporter must pay their income tax quarterly to CRA
When reporters receive income from work, a percentage of that income needs to be set aside for tax purposes, including paying CPP (recommendation: 30%)
Taz laws change every year - to make sure reporters are taking advantage of all the tax deductions to them and to avoid the potential of a possible audit, they may want to seek professional help
Tax calculator: https://simpletax.ca/calculator?&gclid=EAIaIQobChMIxbObrYTA5wIVj8VkCh3wUgo5EAAYAyABEgLZ_fD_BwE
Tax deduction: reduces the amount of income that's subject to tax (e.g., operational court reporting expenses, RRSPs)
Tax credit: reduces the amount of tax owing
An amount eligible for a tax credit generally creates a federal tax savings based on the lowest tax bracket, 15%
A 10,000 tax credit amount will generate $1,500 actual tax credit against taxes owing, which means your tax bill is lower by $1,500 (10,000 x 15%)
The calculation is the same no matter the tax bracket (e.g., tuition expenses, donations, student loan interest, medical expenses, Canada child benefit, child care deduction, age)
Marginal tax rate: the amount of tax paid on any additional dollar made up to the next tax bracket
Average tax rate: percentage of tax paid based on your total taxable income and reflects the total tax you are paying
Tax Deductions
the reporter doesn't have to claim the deduction in the year they purchased the item
some of the deductions reporters generally are allowed include:
Anything purchased to help reporters perform their job, including shorthand machine, computer hardware and software. Some items are depreciated over time (shorthand machine) and some can be written off 100% at the time of purchase (software).
Depending on the working arrangement with the firm, car expenses including gas and maintenance. A log needs to be kept of business versus personal travel including date, destination, purpose, and number of kilometres driven (see example).
Full cost of some utility expenses, including home Internet and phone expenses if used for the job.
Partial cost of other utility expenses, including power and heat. Based on a percentage of office space with the rest of the house (see example).
Any items purchased to create a home office.
Note: Generally, items 3, 4, and 5 can only be claimed if an office is not provided for you at the place you work.
How to Claim Care Expenses
Example
On January 1 the odometer on your vehicle says 10,000 kms.
On December 31 the odometer on your vehicle says 30,000 kms.
By keeping a log, you determine 5,000 kms. were business related.
From this example, you are able to write off 25% of your vehicle expenses. 5,000/20,000=25%
Note: There are different rules for a purchased vehicle.
Write-Offa Include:
- Leasing
- Gas
- Servicing and Repairs
- Insurance
- Parts
- Licence and Registration fees
- Car Washes
- Note: Parking is a 100% write-off if done for business purposes.
How to Claim Home Expenses
Layout Particulars
- Apartment is 1,000 square feet
- Office is 100 square feet (10 x10)
- 100/1,000 means you can write off 10% of the following items:
- Rent (get advice)
- Gas and electricity
- Water
- General home repairs not particular to a given room.
- You can still write of 100% of the following items:
- Internet
- Cell phone
- Items and repairs for your office only (some of these may be depreciated)
Tax rates
based on taxable income
Canada Tax Brackets for 2023

Alberta Tax Brackets for 2023

Tax Rate Example

Assumption: Reporter had taxable income of $70,000 working in Alberta.
- Federal tax: $7,798
- Provincial tax: $4,149
- CPP Deduction: $7,509
- Total tax to be paid: $19,455
- Net Pay: $50,545
- Average Tax Rate: 18.21%
- Marginal Tax Rate: 30.5%
Employment Insurance Benefits for the Self-Employed
Optional benefit a self-employed person can pay for through a tax deduction.
Benefit: Financial support of up to 55% of earnings to maximum of $650 per week (2023).
Types of benefits: maternity, parental, sickness, family caregiver for children, compassionate care.
Conditions:
Be registered in self-employed program for at least 12 months
Decreased the amount of time you spend on your business by more than 40% for at least one week.
Have earned a minimum amount of net self-employed earnings between January 1 and December 31 of the year before you apply for benefits.
How to register:
Register online for the program through My Service Canada Account (MSCA)
Pay EI premiums
You can apply for special benefits 12 months after your confirmed registration date.
Estimate of Premiums
For 2023, you will pay $1.63 in EI premiums for every $100 earned to a maximum of $1,002.45. (Rate changes annually)
Same rate as an employee would pay.
NOTE: “Once you receive benefits as a self-employed person, you’ll continue paying premiums for as long as you’re self-employed.”
Expense Accounts
Arrangements are usually made for reporters to be reimbursed when they have to travel out of town. If the reporter is paying for the expenses out their own pocket (to be reimbursed later), it is best to pay with a credit card. If the reporter happens to lose their receipt, then they will still have a record of the transaction.
When reporters do out-of-town work and receive money for meals and/or mileage (e.g., $50 per day for meals and 50 cents a kilometer), they do not have to claim that money as income on their income tax returns.
If a reporter does receive money for mileage, they cannot claim that trip as a taxable vehicle expense on their income tax return.
GST - Goods and Services Tax
When Must GST Registration Take Place?
You have 29 days to apply for GST registration from the day that your business exceeds the small supplier threshold amount.
If on June 1 your revenues go over $30,000, you have until June 29 to apply for registration.
Note: June 1 would be my effective GST registration date, and I will be responsible for collecting GST/HST from that date.
How to register for the GST
GST registration with the CRA is fairly easy. You can register by phone, online, by mail or drop into your local CRA office. What's the GST Registration Process provides the phone numbers and addresses you need.
When you've registered, you'll be assigned a business number. This is a business identification number that you'll use for all your dealings with the CRA.
https://www.canada.ca/en/revenue-agency/services/tax/businesses/topics/registering-your-business/register.html

item.title: NCRA Position Statements
item.description:
This page was last updated October 2024


Attorneys are responsible for court reporting fees unless stated otherwise


NCRA advocates for high standards in CART
Only qualified professionals provide these services
Student involvement should be limited and supervised to maintain quality


NCRA supports laws that protect the confidentiality and accuracy of outsourced transcription
NCRA emphasizes the importance of maintaining control over sensitive information


Court reporters must disclose any contracting relationships with parties involved in cases and must remain impartial
NCRA promotes laws to limit such contracting arrangements to maintain ethical standards


NCRA argues against reducing the number of official court reporters
NCRA emphasizes their critical role in maintaining accurate and secure records


Concerns arise over online repositories that may share confidential transcripts without permission
NCRA insists that such sharing should be prohibited unless proper safeguards are in place


NCRA supports electronic access to court records but stresses the need for privacy measures and compensation adjustments for reporters impacted by e-filing systems


NCRA recommends the use of certified specialists for legal video to ensure proper standards are met


NCRA has a policy against engaging with online trolls, promoting non-engagement to protect its members

item.title: COPE Guidelines for Professional Practice
item.description:
This page was last updated October 2024
See full guidelines here: https://www.ncra.org/home/the-profession/NCRA-Code-of-Professional-Ethics/cope---guidelines-for-professional-practice


Accept appropriate assignments
Only take assignments where you can produce an accurate transcript - if your skills are inadequate, recommend another qualified reporter
Prepare the record properly
Follow transcript-preparation guidelines set by statute, court order, or local practices
Qualified substitutes
Ensure any substitute reporter is qualified for the assignment
Preserve notes
Keep shorthand notes for at least five years, either as original paper notes or electronic copies
Meet deadlines
Aim to deliver transcripts on time and notify clients of any delays
Continuous improvement
Stay proficient and up-to-date with current literature and technology; participate in continuing-education programs
Support the profession
Participate in activities that enhance the quality and standards of reporting
Cooperate with justice
Work with the legal community to improve the administration of justice
Pro bono services
Offer pro bono services when requested through qualified legal aid organizations, maintaining impartiality, competence, and integrity


Clarify services needed
Determine who will require realtime services before starting
Use discretion in assignments
Accept assignments based on skill level and accurately represent your qualifications
Prepare in advance
Gather materials beforehand to create a job dictionary
Technical proficiency
Be knowledgeable about your software & hardware and able to troubleshoot basic issues
Ongoing education
Pursue further knowledge through workshops, meetings, and certification
Draft transcript disclaimer
Include a disclaimer with uncertified drafts stating they cannot be quoted or filed in court, and keep a copy for your records


Aid justice
The primary goal is to assist in the administration of justice
Distinguish versions
Understand that there will be an unofficial and an official transcript for each proceeding; uncertified drafts may contain errors and cannot be filed with the court
Limit distribution
Uncertified transcripts should only go to the involved parties, not the public
Professional conduct
Maintain professionalism and comply with all relevant laws during the transcript preparation
Maintain impartiality
Avoid any situations that might compromise your neutrality or the accuracy of the record
Clearly mark drafts
Label each page as "uncertified draft transcript only" and avoid including elements that indicate finality
Handle untranslated content
Resolve any untranslated steno strokes before providing drafts, if possible
Minimum standards
Ensure that your writing skills meet the guidelines before distributing drafts, but you can provide them later if needed


Ensure integrity
Comply with local, state, and federal laws regarding the integrity of the record
Understand "work product"
Recognize that backup recordings made at your discretion are your personal property and not public records
Providing backup audio media
Ensure no confidential discussions are included before sharing
Provide copies, not originals, unless ordered by a court
Offer the same access to all parties if sharing media
Offering as a value-added service
Inform all parties before proceedings start
Ensure recordings do not distort the record and contain no confidential discussions


Logistical issues
Encourage all counsel to be on camera, including the reporter
Ensure everyone in the room is visible on camera
Avoid multiple microphones to prevent feedback
Reporting proceedings
Interrupt as needed to maintain an accurate record
Identify all participants clearly
If disconnection occurs, notify participants and request a repeat of missed statements
Transcript production
Clearly note that the proceeding was remote in the transcript
Use appropriate notations for technical difficulties and unidentified speakers
Recording considerations
Be designated as host to prevent unauthorized recordings
Remind all parties that recording is not allowed unless consented

Some advice as you begin your search:

Set a budget and buy the most RAM and hard drive space available within your budget.
A solid-state drive (SSD) is recommended over an HDD, but either one will suit your needs.
Consider the weight of the laptop as you will be carrying is around when you start working. You can purchase an external monitor and wireless keyboard/mouse for use at home to increase your workspace.
Keyboard and touchpad - try it before you buy it! Type on it and see how it feels, if it's noisy, and whether your finger can easily reach the enter key. Some keyboards have the enter key a little farther away which makes it harder to reach.
A minimum of three UDB ports. If the laptop you like has less than three, you may want to purchase a USB hub. The ports are needed to hook up various devices to your computer.

item.title: Role of the Court Reporter
item.description:
Arrive 30 minutes before the proceeding is set to commence (45-60 minutes if it's videotaped or realtime)
Introduce yourself when you enter the law office
Set up at one end of the table in the discovery room
Preferably away from the door
Consider where the electrical outlets and coffee stations are located
Introduce yourself and hand out business cards to lawyers


Set up your equipment first
Make sure everything is working properly
Request a style of cause
The examining lawyer will have the style of cause
Ask for a copy of it or ask if you can take a picture of it
It must be written exactly the same way as it's given to you, including capitalization and/or spelling errors
If time permits, quickly scan the style of cause for spellings and to learn about the case you're about to write


When working with unfamiliar counsel, ask for their name and who they represent
Examples:
Unfamiliar Counsel
Court Reporter: Sir, may I have your name, please.
Lawyer: John R. Jones
Court Reporter: And whom do you represent?
Lawyer: I am on for the plaintiff. Familiar Counsel
Court Reporter: Mr. Jones, who are you representing today?
Lawyer: I am on for the plaintiff, Martin Wilson.
Always ask for the witness's full name
*Would you please state your name.
Could you tell me your full name, please.
If the witness's name is on the style of cause, you may confirm the spelling.
Is this the correct spelling of your name?
If the witness's name is not on the style of cause, ask them to spell their name.
If the witness's name is different on the style of cause, confirm the correct spelling.
Information Sheet

Keep track of names, spellings, and times of the examination in a notebook or an information sheet.
Some firms will provide you with a template. Billing from expected start time in brackets, not actual start time. Good place to track exhibit numbers.
(10:00)
10:10 -
Martin John Wilson
Examined by Counsel Jones
Setup

Make dictionary entries, speaker IDs, and get yourself ready to write.
Do whatever it takes to feel comfortable before the proceeding starts.
Administering the oath

Administer an oath to the witness prior to examination commencing.
Ask if the witness would like to swear on the Bible or take an affirmation. Counsel will help you to explain if the witness doesn't understand the difference (promise to tell the truth vs. swearing to tell the truth on a Bible)
Make eye contact with the witness while administering the oath.
State the oath in a firm and steady voice.
Oath with a Bible:
Do you solemnly swear the evidence you are about the give will be the truth, the whole truth, and nothing but the truth so help you God?
Affirmation:
Do you solemnly affirm the evidence you are about to give will be the truth, the whole truth, and nothing but the truth?
People with religious beliefs other than Christian may choose to make an affirmation
People with no religious beliefs may choose to make an affirmation
With an interpreter:
First administer the oath to the interpreter:
Do you solemnly swear to well and truly interpret from the English language to the language and from the language to the English language to the best of your skill and ability so help you God?
Do you solemnly affirm to well and truly interpret from the English language to the language and from the language to the English language to the best of your skill and ability so help you God?
Then administer the oath to the witness through the interpreter.
Example SOC


Main role during the proceeding is to write it verbatim, but other tasks include:
Dealing with discussions off the record
Reporter readbacks
Anticipating counsel interjections
Interrupting speakers
Marking exhibits
Obtaining proper spellings
Indicating non-verbal actions
Handling heated arguments, asides, and conversation by third parties
Handling adjournments
Marking Exhibits

At pretrial proceedings, exhibits are marked by the reporter by affixing an exhibit stamp.  The exhibit stamp should be red in color and should be filled out by the reporter with a blue pen. This is to clearly distinguish a document marked as an exhibit from any copies that may later be made.
You may use pre-made stickers instead of stamps if they fit on the document being marked
To facilitate quick reference by counsel, placement of the exhibit stamp should be the top right corner of any document. If the top right corner is not available, place the stamp as close to the top of the document as possible. If there is no place on the entire face of the document to put the exhibit stamp, place the stamp on the back of the document.
It is prudent practice to let counsel know that you are putting the exhibit stamp on the back of the document.
Make sure when you are placing the stamp, that the stamp does not touch any written portion of the document.
When marking photographs, have prepared exhibit stamp stickers to place on the back of the photograph. The ink smudges when you stamp the back of photographs (with the shiny finish).  Stickers are often used for documents as well.
The reporter would include the following information in the exhibit stamp:

Sequential number (or letter if marked for identification)
Full name of witness (same as given when sworn in, all caps)
Date of examination
Reporter’s name and initials
Full exhibits receive a number designation ("D" for discovery):
“Pasted image 20240718000440.png” could not be found.
Exhibits for identification receive a letter designation:
“Pasted image 20240718000549.png” could not be found.
OR
“Pasted image 20240718000559.png” could not be found.
Exhibits marked in a cross-examination on Affidavit do not have the letter "D":
“Pasted image 20240718000626.png” could not be found.
Discussions off the Record

The reporter goes off the record only when both sides agree to go off the record
If opposing counsel gives no response or any type of indication to the requesting counsel wanting to go off the record, the reporter can assume opposing counsel is fine with going off the record.
The reporter should make it obvious that he or she is not writing anything that is being said.  Make an attempt to be obvious that you are off the record.
When counsel make the request to go off the record, it is recorded in the transcript unless the lawyer talks directly to the reporter only to go off the record; however, when the request is made to go back on the record, that is not included in the transcript.
When counsel are discussing whether or not to go off the record, that is included in the transcript.
Interrupting Speakers

Unlike clarifying the spelling of a word, you must make the interruption immediately to clarify something not heard or understood. If you hesitate, the speakers move on, and it is difficult to capture the moment again.
Say something short and to the point (“pardon me”) while making eye contact with the speaker. 
If you are clarifying a word that you think is the response but are not satisfied, repeat the response to the speaker.  For example: Did you say “yes”? If you didn’t hear an answer, don’t expect your audio to pick up the sound.
If you are unsure whether you heard a name or word correctly and can put that word into context later, make a notation and clarify the word during a break. If it's a proper name, you will have to get the spelling anyway.
Witnesses with accents can be difficult to understand, so be sure to advise examining counsel you are experiencing this difficulty.  Lawyers can then change the way they ask questions and will understand if you are interrupting often.
To clarify the spelling of a word, make a notation in your transcript. "Oops" is a good Case CAT feature for this! You can then ask your questions at the next break. A good resource for the spelling of proper nouns is from the documents themselves. Otherwise, you will direct your question to the witness or counsel to get a spelling. Record the information directly into your transcript or on your information page. 
The internet is a great resource for researching names of geographic areas, company names, street names, etc. 
It should be the goal of the reporter to clarify any information needed before they leave the discovery room. It will save time when editing.
You can try to tell a witness to slow down, but it often doesn't work. Do not interrupt if the lawyer is going for the "kill," the witness is reacting to the questions and not thinking, don't spoil the lawyer's train of thought or give the witness time to think.
Interjections

One of the biggest adjustments NAIT graduates have when they start out in industry is writing interjections by the witness's lawyer. One way to best deal with this scenario is to anticipate when an interjection or objection will be made.
Here is a list of possible reasons for an interjection or objection from opposing counsel:

Hypothetical questions. Examining counsel are not allowed to ask hypothetical questions, e.g., "If you weren't speeding, do you think the accident would have happened?"
Questions that ask for an opinion. Examining counsel are not allowed to ask for an opinion from the witness unless the witness is called as an expert in a specific field, e.g., "Do you think Mr. Jones did a good job in his position as manager?" gray area when it's about the witness's frame of mind
Questions that do not relate to the pleadings in a questioning for discovery or questions that do not fall within the “four corners” of an affidavit in a cross-examination on affidavit, e.g., if we had a car accident, and the witness was not claiming future loss of income because they got over their injuries after a certain amount of time, examining counsel cannot ask questions about their future employment and potential income
When examining counsel asks for an undertaking - lawyer will usually step in and answer for the witness
When the questioning becomes heated between the counsel and the witness, the witness’s lawyer may interject to protect his or her witness, i.e., they will make an objection just to stop the proceeding and give their witness's a chance to compose themselves again and think about their answers
The body language of the witness’s lawyer. Many times the witness’s lawyer will put his hand in front of witness or move up to the end of his chair so the witness knows not to answer the question and the lawyer can interject.
Note: In Canadian proceedings, witnesses do not answer questions that are objected to. You may see the witness answering in the demo videos from NCRA Career Launcher.
Readbacks

Reporter readbacks must be performed proficiently upon request. Many times the competency of the reporter is judged by their ability to read back.
When asked to read back, take your time. Review your text or vertical notes prior to beginning the readback.
The readback should be in a loud, clear voice at a steady pace (approximately 140 wpm). You must give the speaker identification first, e.g., "Question: Where were you on the night in question? Answer: I was - Speaker: Ms. Smith: Don't answer that."
Readbacks should be read with back-up equipment on. If the readback is not the last question or answer, highlight or mark the spot that was read back, and copy and paste in the appropriate spot.
Sometimes the readback requested is not only the last question asked or answer given but is not specific. If necessary, ask clarifying questions to determine what is being requested to be read.
If you need a few minutes to find the portion to read back or would like to review it with the audio backup, ask for a brief adjournment.
Obtaining Spellings

To clarify the spelling of a word, make a notation in your steno notes or make a note on your information page. You can then get the spelling at the next break.
The best place to get spellings is from the documents themselves. Otherwise, depending on the spelling needed, you will have to ask the witness or possibly counsel to get a spelling. Once you receive the spelling, record the spelling directly into your transcript and/or in the top right-hand corner on the back of your information page. Some spellings, like geography and company names, can also be attained from the Internet.
In terms of spellings, it should be the goal of the reporter to attain all necessary spellings before he/she leaves the questioning room. As the reporter, you don't want to waste time when producing the transcript having to look things up.
Indicating Non-Verbal Actions

When a witness nods his head to indicate “yes” or shakes his head to indicate “no”, counsel may ask for a verbal response.  If they do not, you may indicate to counsel there was no verbal response.
If a witness uses a body motion to answer a question, counsel may describe the motion on the record or ask the witness to describe it.
Q Where did you hit your head?  (Witness points to his head)   (New Paragraph)
I notice you are indicating the left temple area; is that correct?
A Correct. 
If the lawyer doesn't do this, the reporter should interrupt and indicate there was no verbal response on the record.
We do not describe non-verbal actions in the record. There's no way to verify and it can be left to interpretation.
Heated Arguments

If there is a heated argument between counsel and the witness, do not interrupt and do the best you can.
If the heated argument is between counsel and their speech is overlapping, immediately step in and remind them to speak one at a time.
Conversation by Third Parties

If an observer/layperson speaks during a questioning and is not at the time under oath, immediately interject and ask whether the comments are to be included in the record.
If the comments are included in the record, the speaker is identified in colloquy format, e.g., MR. BROWN:
Handling Adjournments

Similar to discussions off the record, all counsel must agree to adjourn.
Like discussions off the record, the reporter quits writing when both sides agree to adjourn.
Apply Professional Conduct During Proceedings

You should provide professional conduct from the time you leave your home until you get back. How you act and present yourself during discussions off the record, adjournments, and in setting up and dismantling your equipment is just as important as when you write the proceeding.


Ask counsel if they would like to order a transcript
Check for delivery deadlines
Regular (5-10 business days)
Expedited (3-5 business days)
Next day
Counsel may sometimes put a transcript order on hold. This means they don't want it produced right away but may order a copy in the future.
Questionings in Aid
Upload backup digital files to your computer
Have all files named and properly organized
Obtain spellings from counsel or witness that you likely won't be able to find yourself
Be personable and polite
Prepare the Transcript

Write
Goal is to get everything down and as accurate as possible. In essence, write like you have no back-up audio.
Ask counsel or the witness for spellings you won't be able to easily find.
Edit with audio
Edit the transcript applying the rules of proper grammar and punctuation
Mark spots where further research may be needed
Proofread with audio
Proofread carefully with the audio
Proofread without audio
Read for context
You don't know what you don't know! Check everything!
Proofreading Tips for New Reporters

New reporters may find proofreading on paper is more effective
Always proofread for context first; ensure the punctuation portrays the correct meaning
Read one word at a time; spelling errors and misused words are common errors
Check the page for proper formatting and speaker tokens
If your mentor is proofreading your transcripts, keep a log of common errors. You don't want to submit transcripts the with same errors

item.title: Continuations
item.description:
Questioning transcripts are witness-based, i.e., each witness's transcript is a discrete document.
E.g., if you take the questioning of 3 witnesses in one day, each witness's transcript will begin with page 1, exhibit 1, and undertaking 1
Court trials/quasi-judicial trials are case-based, i.e., proceedings are continuous and don't start over for each individual witness
Transcript page numbers & exhibit numbers carry on throughout the whole proceeding
Generally speaking, an examining lawyer only gets one chance to examine a witness from the other side during the questioning for discovery stage. However, sometimes a witness is examined at a discovery, and the examining lawyer will not finish his or her questioning or will have finished questioning subject to the undertakings that were given or new documents that may be produced into evidence before trial. When the lawyer comes back to question the witness a second time on a different date, this is called a continuation.
Why might a questioning be continued?
adjourned (to a specified date) or adjourned sine die (to a date in the future)
adjourned subject to the undertakings (very specific adjournment where further questioning may only apply to the undertakings)
reopen a concluded questioning (because new documents were filed or new information has come to light)
At the time the booking is made, the reporting firm will generally ask if it is a continuation so the reporter knows before they attend the discovery.
How else might a reporter know it's a continuation?
Multiday bookings
Firm may advise the proceedings are continued
Counsel may advise the proceedings are continued
Reporter may inquire whether the proceedings are continued
When a reporter is reporting a continuation of a questioning for discovery, they will request the last page number, the last exhibit number, and the last undertaking number from the previous examination.
Paragraph numbers are not applied in Alberta transcripts, but you may encounter them in other jurisdictions (also witness-based and continued on further questioning dates)
The cover page will then read "Continued Questioning for Discovery of ^Witness's Name^"
The reporter at a continuation may ask examining counsel if they would like the witness resworn.  The sworn notation may then read:
^WITNESS'S NAME^, Sworn, Questioned by ^Lawyer's Name^
^WITNESS'S NAME^, Previously Sworn, Questioned by ^Lawyer's Name^

item.title: American Depositions
item.description:
You may find an American lawsuit where one of the witnesses lives in Canada and, as a result, they conduct the deposition here.
Formatting and Title Page

Most firms in Canada will use their regular discovery format.
The style of cause is different in American depositions and will be transposed on the title page in a similar format as that given to them. The rest of the title page will remain the same.
Major Differences Between Questionings and Depositions

In most cases, the transcript is first sent to the witness with a covering letter.
The witness can make any changes to the transcripts it wants to. To do this, the witness will fill out an errata sheet attached to the back of the transcript. The errata sheet will contain (1) the page and line number of each change, (2) the actual change itself, (3) the reason for the change, (4) signature by witness certifying that the deposition is correct as stated with the exceptions noted above, and (5) the date that the errata sheet was filled out.
In administering the oath, the witness raises his right hand, no Bible, no standing. The witness is sworn, not affirmed.
Exhibits marked in the deposition are attached to the back of the transcript and become part of the actual transcript.
The certificate filled out by the reporter is much more in depth.
Having a videographer present in a deposition is much more common that in questionings in Canada.
In most depositions if the witness's counsel makes an objection to a question, the witness still answers the question after the objection has been made. In Canada, the witness will not answer and the examining lawyer will have to go to Chambers and receive a ruling in his favor to get the witness to answer.
American lawyers, when they conduct a deposition in Canada, almost always pay in American dollars.

item.title: Proceedings
item.description:
Virtual proceedings are secure, economic, and just as effective as in-person proceedings.

Accounts needed/must be familiar with the following:
Zoom
WebEx
Microsoft Teams
Adobe Connect
Either the firm or the individual court reporter will invite participants
Preparation

Start time (arrive 30 minutes before start time)
Introduce yourself to each person and confirm their identity/their role
Troubleshooting? Some people may require guidance (mute/unmute button, video on/off button)
Introductory statements - set the tone! Explain your role and what participants can do if things go wrong during the examination. Some good tips to provide include:
Speak one at a time
Wait for the speaker to finish before they begin
Make audible answers
Obtain the information you need (style of cause, determine the appearance, whether or not the questioning is a continuation, and the full name of the witness)
Administer oath
Press record! If recording directly to Zoom/platform is use, ask permission from all of the people attending the meeting
Audio Issues

Identify and address audio issues right away by speaking to each participant in the meeting
To mute or not to mute? Easier to interrupt if unmuted, depends on background noise, good idea to connect foot pedal to mute/unmute
Connections (may be difficult to hear if a participant doesn't have good internet connection)
Hardwired! connect directly to your router during proceedings - Wi-Fi is not a stable enough environment to avoid connection issues
Phone - have a participant phone into a meeting if there are audio issues
Interrupt when you don't hear parts of a lawyer's question or a witness's answer!
Headphones - direct participants to use headphones if there's an echo
Exhibits

Some counsel may send these in advance and some after the proceedings
Use stamps feature in Adobe to mark exhibits
When counsel marks an exhibit, make a statement on the record, e.g., "That would be Exhibit D-5." Include the statement on the record and make the notation in your transcript.
Add Stamp shortcut: Tools menu > Share & Review > Stamp > Add stamp tool to shortcuts

Add stamp to document: Stamp > Category, Name > Click to place stamp on document > Fill & Sign in toolbar > fill in exhibit information on the stamp > File > Save marked exhibit as "Exhibit D-1 - Witness's Name"
Breaks

Mute participants
Turn off video
Make note of the expected time of return and turn on video to indicate at that time that you are ready
Display a picture or a document during a break indicating that the proceedings are on pause by using the share screen function
Conclusion

Follow the same steps as in-person proceedings
Confirm orders
Check for spellings
End the meeting for all participants
If counsel requests to stay in the meeting with their client, assign them the host and leave the meeting

item.title: Quasi-Judicial Hearings
item.description:
Characteristics:

Impartiality: The Administrative Law Judge (ALJ) or panel must act impartially and without bias.
Due Process: Parties are entitled to due process, including the right to present evidence, cross-examine witnesses, and receive a fair hearing.
Record-Keeping: A detailed record of the proceedings is maintained for transparency and review purposes.
Expertise: The decision-makers are often experts in the relevant field, allowing for informed and specialized judgments.
Quasi-judicial hearings blend elements of formal judicial procedures with the practicalities and expertise of administrative bodies, ensuring that disputes and regulatory matters are resolved fairly and efficiently within their specific contexts.

The quasi-judicial hearing process involves administrative agencies or bodies that perform functions similar to those of a court, but within the context of their specific areas of expertise. These hearings are often related to regulatory, administrative, or disciplinary actions. Here is an overview of the quasi-judicial hearing process:

Complaint/Petition: The process begins with the filing of a complaint, petition, or application by an individual, organization, or government entity. This initiates the case and sets the procedural wheels in motion.
Notice of Hearing: The parties involved are notified about the hearing. This notice includes the date, time, place, and nature of the hearing, ensuring that all parties have adequate time to prepare.


Preliminary Conference: Sometimes, a preliminary conference is held to clarify issues, set timelines, and discuss procedural matters.
Discovery: Similar to judicial proceedings, parties may engage in discovery to gather evidence and information from each other.


Administrative Law Judge (ALJ): The hearing is typically presided over by an Administrative Law Judge or a panel. The ALJ or panel acts as an impartial arbiter.
Opening Statements: Both parties may present opening statements to outline their positions and the evidence they intend to present.
Presentation of Evidence: Evidence is presented by both sides. This includes witness testimonies, documents, and other relevant materials. Witnesses may be cross-examined by the opposing party.
Rules of Evidence: While formal rules of evidence may be relaxed compared to judicial proceedings, the ALJ ensures that evidence presented is relevant and reliable.
Record of Proceedings: The entire hearing is typically recorded and transcribed to ensure there is an accurate record for review.


Briefs and Arguments: Parties may be allowed to submit post-hearing briefs or written arguments summarizing their positions and the evidence presented.
Deliberation and Decision: The ALJ or panel reviews the evidence and arguments, deliberates, and makes a decision based on the merits of the case.
Findings of Fact and Conclusions of Law: The decision includes findings of fact and conclusions of law, detailing the reasoning behind the decision.
Issuance of Decision: The decision is issued in writing and provided to all parties involved. This document outlines the outcome and any orders or sanctions imposed.


Internal Appeals: There may be an internal appeals process within the agency or body, where the decision can be reviewed by a higher authority within the same organization.
Judicial Review: Parties dissatisfied with the decision may seek judicial review in a court of law. The court reviews the administrative record and determines whether the quasi-judicial body acted within its authority and followed proper procedures.


Implementation of Decision: The decision is enforced as per the agency's or body's rules. This may involve sanctions, penalties, or other actions as prescribed in the decision.
Compliance Monitoring: The agency may monitor compliance with the decision and take further action if necessary.

item.title: StenoTab
item.description:
Welcome! StenoTab is a compilation of all my notes from NAIT's Captioning and Court Reporting program. I created this site for 3 reasons: 1. I strongly believe that knowledge should be free and accessible to everyone 2. I want to help foster a community where the success of one is the success of all 3. I hope to inspire people to explore the field, whether as a potential career or to appreciate its important role in the legal system and our lives, in general

Stenography 1: the art or process of writing in shorthand
2: shorthand especially written from dictation or oral discourse
3: the making of shorthand notes and subsequent transcription of them Merriam-Webster.com
Captioners and court reporters are professionals who can type at speeds of 225 words per minute or more with at least 95% accuracy using a steno machine. We turn spoken words into written text using our machine and computer technology.
Being a captioner or court reporter is a unique and exciting career. Every day is different, and you get to learn new and interesting things all the time. Plus, it has the potential to be quite lucrative. Career opportunities include:

Broadcast Captioner (live television events and internet programs)
CART Provider (real-time transcription in educational, corporate, or community settings)
Court Reporter (court trials, examinations for discovery, and hearings)
But there’s a lot to learn beyond just typing well!

Are we being replaced by AI? Short answer: No. Long answer: I don't believe it will be possible to replace court reporters with AI, and this belief stems from two main factors: human cognition and accountability. Human cognition is essential to what we do. Court reporters manage fast speech, accents, crosstalk, mumbling, and background noise in real-time and can ask for clarification on ambiguous terms. We can interrupt the proceedings to ascertain what the speaker said if we missed it. "Fifteen" can sound like "fifty," just as "B" can sound like "V." Plus, homophones exist – for example, did the speaker say "write" or "right"? Context plays a vital role too. Did the officer say "No. Shots were fired," or did he say "No shots were fired"? A court reporter can hear the distinction; AI can't. And what error rate would you or your client be okay with? 10%? 20%? Hiring a certified court reporter guarantees a near perfect transcript. Additionally, AI datasets have shown significant racial biases. Court reporters ensure the accuracy of the record as impartial third parties. We certify transcripts and are legally responsible for errors. In other words, we display unbiased accountability. Who would be accountable if AI takes down the record incorrectly? The party providing the AI, the company that owns it, or the legal system? Many US courtrooms have already banned AI entirely, and I believe this issue was a major factor in those decisions. The other concern is privacy. One of the 12 major risks to the use of AI is insecurity. There have been multiple occasions when faulty data storage practices resulted in leaked personal data. AI simply cannot be incorporated into a legal setting in its current state. Plus, if AI has advanced to the point of replacing humans, I think it’s safe to say that we won’t be the only profession affected.
What is digital reporting? A digital reporter operates an audio recording device to capture what happens during a proceeding. The make minimal "tag notes" to identify speakers and highlight key moments, but their only record is the audio file itself. They don't take down a complete word-for-word account of everything said and don't use stenography. If the equipment fails due to technical issues or user error, there's no backup. This could seriously harm a case. Once the recording is made, the digital reporter’s job is essentially done. They aren’t responsible for creating the final transcript. Instead, the audio is broken up into smaller clips and sent to transcriptionists, often located in other countries. These transcriptionists listen to the clips and type out what they hear, and then the agency assembles the final transcript. The digital reporter often doesn’t review the final transcript or the recording, yet may still falsely certify it as accurate. As you can probably imagine, there are major problems with this process. Since they're relying on recordings, the final transcript is often full of errors or missing sections. One attorney in California, Melissa B. Buchman, submitted a piece to the Los Angeles & San Francisco Daily Journal about an experience she had with a digital reporter where 55 pages (an entire hour of testimony) was completely left out of the final transcript. Another issue is that digital reporters don’t handle the security of sensitive information like names, addresses, or birth dates. If there’s a data breach, personal details could be exposed, increasing the risk of identity theft. The way transcripts are shared and stored makes it harder to protect that information. With digital reporting, there’s just no guarantee of accuracy or confidentiality, leaving room for mistakes and potential security risks. If you're looking into schooling for court reporting, my recommendation is to make sure it's not digital reporting.
Why not record everything? Recording still needs transcription, which is less efficient and secure. Multiple transcriptionists are needed to match the output of one stenographer, increasing errors and confidentiality risks. Recording alone is outdated.
Is there a shortage of court reporters? I'll only speak to the situation here in Alberta, but I believe this issue is common in many parts of Canada and the US. In September 2023, Court of King’s Bench Chief Justice Mary Moreau issued a memo about the use of court reporters in legal proceedings. The memo mentioned a shortage of reporters, which didn’t accurately reflect the situation. ASRA President Di Rocco pointed out that Alberta has 145 certified reporters, a number that’s stable and growing thanks to training programs like NAIT’s. Since these concerns were raised, no trials have gone uncovered, and ASRA was able to bring their issues directly to the Chief of Staff for the Minister of Justice in 2024. Despite this, some argue that court reporters aren’t needed and off-site transcription is good enough. Shawn King, vice-president of the Criminal Trial Lawyers’ Association, shared this view but acknowledged that off-site transcriptions aren’t always accurate. This is especially true when dealing with unclear audio or background noise, issues an on-site reporter can address in real-time. But here’s the key question: How many errors would you be comfortable with in a transcript? What if it’s a case that directly affects you? What if it’s a serious crime, like a murder or sexual assault case? Would you be okay with a 10% or 20% error rate? At what point do you see the value of having a court reporter in the courtroom? So to answer the question: No, there is not a shortage of court reporters. But the future of the profession is a real and ongoing concern.
How do I get into steno? Where do I start? If you're thinking about a career in steno, you can try out NCRA’s A to Z program (aka Discover Steno, which is also offered by NAIT) for free. It’s a great way to get an introduction to stenography. The program also connects you with experienced court reporters and captioners, so you can ask questions about the field. By the end, you'll have a good understanding of the basics and how to start working toward certification. I took the program myself and highly recommend it; it’s a fantastic way to learn more before committing to a captioning/court reporting program.
If you have any questions or want to connect, feel free to send me an email
